headline: Venezuela moves to cut oil output due to US export embargo
summary:
VIDEO SHOWS:

STORY: Venezuela's state-run oil company PDVSA has begun cutting crude production.

The company is running out of storage capacity due to an ongoing U.S. oil blockade.

:: File

PDVSA's move includes shutting down oilfields or well clusters as onshore stocks mount.

:: Donald Trump via Truth Social

Caracas is in political crisis under an interim government after President Nicolas Maduro and his wife were captured by U.S. forces on Saturday.

:: Kristi Noem via X

Oil exports, Venezuela's main source of revenue, are now at a standstill following a U.S. blockade on tankers under sanctions and the seizure of two crude cargoes last month.

:: Howard Harrison

Shipments by U.S. giant Chevron bound for the United States had been an exception as the company has a license from Washington.

But weekend data shows that even those have now stopped. 

U.S. President Donald Trump said Saturday that an oil embargo on the country was in full force.

Venezuela's oil minister, Delcy Rodriguez, who is now the country's interim president, said last month that the country would continue producing and exporting crude despite the U.S. measures.

But the U.S. pressure has forced PDVSA to store oil in vessels since late December and slow down cargo deliveries at its main port.

If loaded tankers cannot depart, company executives and experts view more output cuts as unavoidable.

Oil prices drifted lower Monday despite the turmoil, as adequate global supplies offset worries about disruption in Venezuela.

content.summary:
VIDEO SHOWS:

:: Kristi Noem via X

Oil exports, Venezuela's main source of revenue, are now at a standstill following a U.S. blockade on tankers under sanctions and the seizure of two crude cargoes last month.

:: Howard Harrison

Shipments by U.S. giant Chevron bound for the United States had been an exception as the company has a license from Washington.

But weekend data shows that even those have now stopped. 

U.S. President Donald Trump said Saturday that an oil embargo on the country was in full force.

Venezuela's oil minister, Delcy Rodriguez, who is now the country's interim president, said last month that the country would continue producing and exporting crude despite the U.S. measures.

But the U.S. pressure has forced PDVSA to store oil in vessels since late December and slow down cargo deliveries at its main port.

If loaded tankers cannot depart, company executives and experts view more output cuts as unavoidable.

Oil prices drifted lower Monday despite the turmoil, as adequate global supplies offset worries about disruption in Venezuela.

headline: Trump’s Venezuela Oil Revival Plan Is a $100 Billion Gamble
summary: Rebuilding it enough to lift Venezuela’s output back to its peak levels of the 1970s would require companies that could include Chevron Corp., Exxon Mobil Corp. and ConocoPhillips to invest about $10 billion per year over the next decade, said Francisco Monaldi, director of Latin American energy policy at Rice University’s Baker Institute for Public Policy.  Venezuela sits atop the world’s largest oil reserves.  US Secretary of State Marco Rubio said during an interview with ABC Sunday that he expects US oil companies will be eager for the opportunity to drill for Venezuela’s heavy crude, which is key for refineries on the US Gulf Coast.

content.title: Trump’s Venezuela Oil Revival Plan Is a $100 Billion Gamble
content.summary: Rebuilding it enough to lift Venezuela’s output back to its peak levels of the 1970s would require companies that could include Chevron Corp., Exxon Mobil Corp. and ConocoPhillips to invest about $10 billion per year over the next decade, said Francisco Monaldi, director of Latin American energy policy at Rice University’s Baker Institute for Public Policy.  Venezuela sits atop the world’s largest oil reserves.  US Secretary of State Marco Rubio said during an interview with ABC Sunday that he expects US oil companies will be eager for the opportunity to drill for Venezuela’s heavy crude, which is key for refineries on the US Gulf Coast.

headline: Gold, Dollar Rise on Venezuela as AI Fuels Stocks: Markets Wrap
summary: Spot gold advanced more than 2% to climb above $4,430 an ounce, while silver jumped 4%.  Nasdaq 100 futures rose 0.5%, with chip stocks such as Advanced Micro Devices Inc. and Micron Technology Inc. gaining more than 2% in premarket trading.  Chevron Corp. rose more than 7% in early trading, alongside sharp gains across US oil majors, after President Donald Trump floated plans for a US-led revival of Venezuela’s industry.

content.title: Gold, Dollar Rise on Venezuela as AI Fuels Stocks: Markets Wrap
content.summary: Spot gold advanced more than 2% to climb above $4,430 an ounce, while silver jumped 4%.  Nasdaq 100 futures rose 0.5%, with chip stocks such as Advanced Micro Devices Inc. and Micron Technology Inc. gaining more than 2% in premarket trading.  Chevron Corp. rose more than 7% in early trading, alongside sharp gains across US oil majors, after President Donald Trump floated plans for a US-led revival of Venezuela’s industry.

headline: The Oil Sector’s Biggest Winners and Losers From Venezuela Regime Change
summary: The capture of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has reopened a question the oil market has largely sidelined for years: What changes if Venezuela’s oil industry begins to normalize under U.S. influence?  In comments today, President Donald Trump says the sanctions on Venezuelan oil remain in place, but he also said that the U.S. intends to be “very involved” in Venezuela’s oil sector, which he says requires billions of dollars fix the “badly broken” oil infrastructure.  While Venezuela currently produces just 1% of global supply, the Wood Mackenzie estimate of $15–20 billion to add 500,000 barrels per day highlights the capital intensity of its extra-heavy crude.

content.title: The Oil Sector’s Biggest Winners and Losers From Venezuela Regime Change
content.summary: The capture of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has reopened a question the oil market has largely sidelined for years: What changes if Venezuela’s oil industry begins to normalize under U.S. influence?  In comments today, President Donald Trump says the sanctions on Venezuelan oil remain in place, but he also said that the U.S. intends to be “very involved” in Venezuela’s oil sector, which he says requires billions of dollars fix the “badly broken” oil infrastructure.  While Venezuela currently produces just 1% of global supply, the Wood Mackenzie estimate of $15–20 billion to add 500,000 barrels per day highlights the capital intensity of its extra-heavy crude.

headline: Wall Street gains ground as crude prices and oil company shares rise after the US raid on Venezuela
summary: Stocks rose in morning trading on Wall Street Monday to kick off the first full week of the new year, led by energy and technology companies.  Energy companies and the oil market were a key focus after U.S. forces captured Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro in a weekend raid.  The price of Brent crude, the international standard, rose 1.1% to $61.43 per barrel.

headline: Venezuela oil: Energy giants likely to invest in infrastructure
summary: Oil prices (CL=F, BZ=F) are rising Monday morning following President Trump's ousting of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro over the weekend. Energy giants are already looking to invest billions of dollars into reviving Venezuela's oil market and rebuilding its oil infrastructure. Hedgeye Risk Management energy analyst Fernando Valle lists the operators and refiners, like Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM), who would have so much to gain from this opportunity. China — one of Venezuela's biggest trade allies for oil — has condemned the invasion. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Opening Bid.

headline: Only Chevron Oil Shipments Moved Out of Venezuela in December, Kpler Says
summary: The U.S blockade of Venezuela has halted virtually all oil movements out of the country, except for shipments made for Chevron, according to Kpler, a trade and ship-tracking intelligence provider.  Since the U.S. seized the Skipper supertanker on Dec. 10, the blockade has created a large backlog for the so-called shadow fleet, trying to load Venezuelan crude destined for China and other Asian markets.  The only crude that successfully left Venezuelan waters since mid-December was 3.5 million barrels of oil bound for the U.S. under a special waiver with Chevron, Kpler said.

content.title: Only Chevron Oil Shipments Moved Out of Venezuela in December, Kpler Says
content.summary: The U.S blockade of Venezuela has halted virtually all oil movements out of the country, except for shipments made for Chevron, according to Kpler, a trade and ship-tracking intelligence provider.  Since the U.S. seized the Skipper supertanker on Dec. 10, the blockade has created a large backlog for the so-called shadow fleet, trying to load Venezuelan crude destined for China and other Asian markets.  The only crude that successfully left Venezuelan waters since mid-December was 3.5 million barrels of oil bound for the U.S. under a special waiver with Chevron, Kpler said.

headline: Oil stocks sharply higher after US action in Venezuela
summary: Shares of major U.S. companies in the energy sector are sharply higher Monday after President Donald Trump announced plans to take control of Venezuela’s oil industry, saying that it would be American companies helping to revitalize it following the capture of President Nicolás Maduro.  While the U.S. action is unlikely to have an immediate impact on crude prices given the current glut in the market, it could upend energy markets and have an impact on the geopolitical landscape.  U.S. control of the Venezuelan energy industry, which sits on the world’s largest oil reserves, could “reshape the balance of power in international energy markets,” analysts with JP Morgan wrote Monday.

content.title: Oil stocks sharply higher after US action in Venezuela
content.summary: Shares of major U.S. companies in the energy sector are sharply higher Monday after President Donald Trump announced plans to take control of Venezuela’s oil industry, saying that it would be American companies helping to revitalize it following the capture of President Nicolás Maduro.  While the U.S. action is unlikely to have an immediate impact on crude prices given the current glut in the market, it could upend energy markets and have an impact on the geopolitical landscape.  U.S. control of the Venezuelan energy industry, which sits on the world’s largest oil reserves, could “reshape the balance of power in international energy markets,” analysts with JP Morgan wrote Monday.

headline: Rush for gold and US oil shares after Trump's Venezuela strike
summary: Demand for "safe haven" metals - gold, silver and copper - and US oil shares have soared as financial markets react to Donald Trump's intervention in Venezuela, helping the FTSE 100 to a milestone in the process.  Shares in energy majors including Chevron and Exxon Mobil were sharply higher in New York in the wake of the operation to capture Venezuelan president Nicolas Maduro.  President Trump has said American oil companies will "fix" oil infrastructure in the South American nation - home to the world's largest oil reserves.

headline: Chevron helps lift Dow to record as oil market weighs Venezuela shake-up
summary: Oil prices finished higher Monday on a heady day for global equities after the US capture of Venezuela's president sparked speculation on the implications for future crude supplies.But then oil prices recovered again as investors realized that Venezuela is in no position to make a meaningful impact on oil supply in the short run, even with all the investment that US President Donald Trump has promised.

headline: The Dow Hits a Record Close
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average got its first all-time high of 2026—but fell just short of closing above 49000 for the first time.  The index was up as much as 1.7% in midday trading, then faded a bit to end the day at 48977.18, up 1.2%.  The move to a new closing high came in part thanks to a jump in shares of Chevron, the sole remaining U.S. oil major in Venezuela.

content.title: The Dow Hits a Record Close
content.summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average got its first all-time high of 2026—but fell just short of closing above 49000 for the first time.  The index was up as much as 1.7% in midday trading, then faded a bit to end the day at 48977.18, up 1.2%.  The move to a new closing high came in part thanks to a jump in shares of Chevron, the sole remaining U.S. oil major in Venezuela.
